Graphical abstract CeSmOx mixed oxide catalysts supported on TiO2 prepared by coprecipitation method were used for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3. The results showed that the addition of Sm could effectively enhance the low-temperature SCR activity and SO2/H2O resistance of Ce/TiO2 catalyst, and the appropriate mole ratio of Sm to Ce was 0.3. Characterization results indicated that the introduction of Sm could promote the formation of Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen species on catalyst surface, which was favorable to the generation of NO2. Moreover, the doping of Sm could also promote the adsorption of NH3 and NOx species on Ce/TiO2 catalyst. The results of in situ DRIFT study revealed that the NH3-SCR reaction over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst was mainly controlled by the Langmuir−Hinshelwood mechanism in the low temperature range (<200°C). Thereafter, the promoted NO oxidation and the enhanced NH3 adsorption should play a major role for the excellent low-temperature SCR performance of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst. Keywords NH3-SCR Activity Ce/TiO2 catalyst Sm Mechanism 1 Introduction NOx emitted from stationary and mobile sources in the combustion process of fossil fuels has brought about a series of environmental problems including acid rain, photochemical smog and ozone depletion etc. [1–3]. To remove NOx from the exhaust gas from stationary sources such as coal-fired boilers in power plants, selective catalytic reduction process, as the predominant technology, has been put into widely industrial application during the past several decades [4–6]. Industrially adopted catalysts used in this process are mainly based on vanadium oxides such as V2O5-WO3/TiO2 (V2O5-WO3/TiO2), which only exhibit high activity in a narrow temperature window range of 300–400°C [7–10]. Moreover, there are still some other drawbacks associated with this type catalyst, including the high conversion of SO2 to SO3, formation of N2O at high temperature and the toxicity of vanadia [11–15]. Besides that, the deactivation of vanadia-based catalyst by SO2 and alkali metals greatly decreases its operation availability [16–20]. As an alternative of vanadia-based catalyst, low-temperature SCR catalyst could work effectively in the temperature range of 80–260°C, thus the SCR reactor could be installed downstream of the electrostatic precipitator and the desulfurization units, as a result, the deactivation caused by SO2 and alkali metals could be avoided to a great extent. Moreover, the toxicity of vanadia to human health and environment is no longer the case. Therefore, it is of urgent need to develop new environmental-friendly catalyst with high SCR performance at low-temperature for further application. Nowadays, ceria-based SCR catalyst has become a research focus due to the high oxygen storage capacity and excellent redox properties of ceria [21,22]. In recent years, a series of Ce-based catalyst have been prepared and used in NH3-SCR reaction, such as Ce/TiO2 [23], Ce-Cu/TiO2 [24], and Ce-W/TiO2 [25]. The study of Yu et al. [26] found that the treatment of Ce/TiO2 catalyst could greatly enhance its SCR performance. Wang et al. [27] reported that the addition of ceria into MIL-100(Fe) could enhance its SCR activity at low temperature due to the promoted formation of NO2. Krishna et al. [28] indicated that the synergetic effect between CeO2 and the zeolite Brønsted acidity was responsible for the high SCR activity of CeO2-zeolite catalysts. And the study of Li et al. [29] revealed that the modification of Ce/TiO2 catalyst by proper amount of Mo could effectively enhance its SCR activity and H2O/SO2 resistance. However, these catalysts still exhibit insufficient low-temperature activity or/and suffer the deactivation by SO2 or/and H2O. It has been proven that the active temperature window of Ce/TiO2 catalyst is about 250–350°C [30], which is only a little lower than that of V-based catalyst. Therefore, enhancing the low-temperature SCR activity of Ce/TiO2 catalyst is still in great demand. Recently, some rare earths have been used to enhance the performance of SCR catalyst. The study of Chen et al. [31] pointed out that the introduction of Nd could greatly enhance the SCR activity of CeO2/ASC catalyst, which was mainly due to the presence of more Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies over CeO2-Nd/ASC catalyst. Ding et al. [32] found that the addition of Nb could enhance the activity and hydrothermal stability of CeZr2Ox catalyst, as a result from the promoted redox ability and the enhanced adsorption and reactivity of reactant species. Similar effect of Sm on MnOx catalyst has also been reported by Meng et al. [33]. Although the low-temperature activity of MnOx catalyst was greatly improved by the addition of Sm, however, the active temperature window is still relatively narrow, and an obvious activity drop over Sm-Mn-0.1 catalyst could be found when the reaction temperature was over 200°C. In this study, Sm is chosen as the additive to enhance the NH3-SCR performance of Ce/TiO2 catalyst. Experimental results indicated that CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst showed excellent SCR activity along with high N2 selectivity and good SO2/H2O resistance. Furthermore, the promotion mechanism of Sm on Ce/TiO2 catalyst was investigated and discussed based on the characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalyst samples were prepared by coprecipitation method. All the chemicals used in this study were supplied by Aladdin Reagent Company of Shanghai with an analytical grade. When preparing Ce/TiO2 catalyst, titanium sulfate (0.1mol) and cerium nitrate (0.02mol) were solved in deionized water. Next then, ammonia solution (3mol/L) was added to the solution dropwisely under adequate stirring at room temperature until the pH value reached 11. After filtration and washing with deionized water, the sediment was dried at 100°C overnight and subsequently calcined at 500°C for 5h under air atmosphere. Similarly, CeSmOx/TiO2 (Ce/Ti molar ratio=0.2) and Sm/TiO2 (Sm/Ti molar ratio=0.2) catalyst samples were prepared by the same method. Samarium nitrate was used as the precursor of Sm. For convenience, the catalyst samples based on CeSmOx with different Sm contents were denoted as CeSm/TiO2-y, where y represents the molar ratio of Sm/Ce. 2.2 Characterization The textural properties of the catalyst samples were tested on a Quantachrome Autosorb- iQ-AG instrument by N2 adsorption at −196°C. Then the specific surface area and the pore size distribution were determined based on the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ=0.15418nm). To determine the chemical states of the elements on catalyst surface, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy with Al Kα X-ray radiation (hν=1486.6eV) was performed on a Thermal ESCALAB 250 spectrometer. The C1s level at 284.8eV was used as the standard for the calibration of binding energy shift. And the XPS spectra were deconvoluted using mixed Gaussian–Lorentzian functions with XPSPeak 4.1 software. The ratio of Gaussian-Lorentzian was kept at 80% in the whole fitting procedure. The temperature programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) was carried out on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-C chemisorption analyzer using 50mg catalyst sample. Prior to each TPR experimental run, the catalyst sample was pretreated at 400°C in Ar for 1h. Then TPR runs were carried out with a linear heating rate of 10°C/min in a gas stream of 5% H2/Ar at a flow rate of 30mL/min. The temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was performed on the same chemisorption analyzer using 0.1g catalyst sample. Firstly, the sample was pretreated in Ar at 400°C for 1h and cooled down to room temperature in Ar flow, followed by saturation with anhydrous NH3 stream (4% in Ar, flow rate=30mL/min) for 30min. Next then, the desorption experiments were carried out by heating the catalyst sample in Ar (30mL/min) from 100 to 500°C. In order to determine the contribution of the products or the reaction between adsorbed NH3 and lattice oxygen, O2-TPD runs were also performed following the same procedure (without NH3 adsorption). The in situ DRIFT experiments were performed on a Nicolet iS 50 FTIR spectrometer with a MCT detector. In the DRIFT cell connected with a gas flow system, the catalyst sample was pretreated in N2 at 500°C for 2h, then it was cooled down to the required temperature in N2. During the DRIFT test, the following conditions were adopted: 600ppm NH3 or/and 600ppm NO+5% O2, and N2 balance, with a total flow rate of 300mL/min. The spectra were recorded by accumulating 100 scans with a resolution of 4cm−1. And the background was subtracted from the sample spectrum at corresponding temperature. 2.3 Activity test The SCR performance was tested in a fixed-bed reactor (i.d.=8mm) using about 0.34g sample (80–100mesh). The components of simulated flue gas were set as follows: 600ppm NO, 600ppm NH3, 5% O2, 5% H2O (when used), 100ppm SO2 (when used), and Ar balance. The total flow rate was 1L/min, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity of 108, 000h−1. Concentrations of NO, NO2, NH3 and N2O were monitored by a Nicolet iS 50 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a gas cell with 0.2dm3 volume. During the test, the data was recorded after 30min when the reaction reached a steady state for each experimental run. The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity could be calculated by the following equations: (1) N O x c o n v e r s i o n = [ NO x ] in − [ NO x ] out [ NO x ] in × 100 % (2) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO x ] in + [ NH 3 ] in − [ NO x ] out − [ NH 3 ] out ) × 100 % Moreover, NO catalytic oxidation test was also performed under the similar conditions without NH3 contained in the simulated flue gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SCR performance The NH3-SCR activities of different catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 1 (A). As can be seen from Fig. 1(A), Sm/TiO2 only exhibits a very low SCR activity, which is not over 50% in the whole temperature zone. The SCR activity of Ce/TiO2 catalyst is much higher than that of Sm/TiO2, but its SCR performance is quite poor in the low temperature range (<250°C). After the addition of Sm, an obvious increase of low temperature SCR activity of Ce/TiO2 catalyst could be observed. It seems that the promotion effect increases with the doping amount of Sm firstly; however, a distinct activity drop could be found when the molar ratio of Sm/Ce reaches 0.5. Among the four CeSm/TiO2 catalyst samples, CeSm/TiO2-0.3 presents the best SCR activity in the whole temperature range. For Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2 catalyst samples, the NOx conversions increase with reaction temperature, but an activity drop could be detected when the reaction temperature is over 400°C, which should be due to the oxidation of NH3 at high temperature. Furthermore, the N2 selectivities over different catalyst samples are illustrated in Fig. 1(B). It is clear that the N2 selectivity of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst is higher than that of the other catalyst samples. In addition, the stabilities of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 and Ce/TiO2 were tested at 250°C and the results are presented in Fig. 1 (C). From Fig. 1(C), it can be seen that the NOx conversion over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst decreases from 98.1% to 94.3% in 48h, as a distinct difference, the NOx conversion over Ce/TiO2 catalyst decreases from 91.9% to 80.5% under the same conditions. Therefore the stability of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 is better than Ce/TiO2, which might be originated from the enhanced thermal stability of actives species in Ce/TiO2 catalyst by the modification with proper amount of Sm. 3.2 SO2 and H2O tolerance It is well recognized that SO2 and H2O present in the flue gas have a poisoning effect on SCR catalyst [34,35]. In this section, the SO2 and H2O tolerance of Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst samples were tested and the results are illustrated in Fig. 2 . As can be seen from Fig. 2, after the introduction of 100ppm SO2 and 5% H2O, the NOx conversion over Ce/TiO2 catalyst drops from about 91% to about 75% in 2h. Correspondingly, the NOx conversion over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 drops from about 99% to 90% in 2h under the same conditions. Moreover, the NOx conversion over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 nearly recovers to its initial value after the cut of SO2 and H2O for 70min. As a comparison, the NOx conversion over Ce/TiO2 catalyst only recovers to about 83%. Thus CeSm/TiO2-0.3 shows excellent SO2 and H2O tolerance, which is of great importance for its industrial application. 3.3 BET and XRD analysis The BET analysis related figures including N2 adsorption-desorption and pore size distribution are shown in Fig. 3 . From Fig. 3, all the adsorption isotherms of the samples exhibit typical type-IV curves with distinct type-H1 hysteresis loops based on the definition of IUPAC, revealing the presence of mesopores. The BJH pore size distributions of most catalyst samples suggest a narrow distribution center at about 10nm, while the pore size distributions of Sm/TiO2 catalyst center at about 7.8nm. Thus the addition of Sm has little effect on the pore size distribution of Ce/TiO2 catalyst. Moreover, the BET surface area and pore structure results of different catalyst samples are summarized in Table 1 . From Table 1, it could be seen that the introduction of Sm into Ce/TiO2 catalyst could increase its BET surface area and pore volume, especially for CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst, which exhibits the largest BET surface area and pore volume among the six catalyst samples. The results should be due to the strong interaction between Ce and Sm in the catalyst samples. But too much Sm addition would not further increase the BET surface area and average pore volume, as shown in the results of CeSm/TiO2-0.5. The enlarged BET surface area and pore volume could facilitate the adsorption of reactant species over catalyst surface and promote the NH3-SCR reaction, which is evidenced by the SCR performance of CeSm/TiO2-0.3. The results of XRD analysis are shown in Fig. 4 . The results indicate that no diffraction peak could be found in the XRD patterns of all the catalyst samples, indicating that Ce, Sm and Ti species are all present in the amorphous phase, which might be resulted from the strong interaction among Ce, Sm and Ti in the catalyst samples. On one hand, the sintering of the catalyst samples used in this study are inhibited during the preparation process [36,37]; one the other hand, the crystalline structures of CeO2 and TiO2 was destroyed in this process [38]. Accordingly, all the catalyst samples exhibit an amorphous phase. So the results of XRD analysis are in good accordance with that of BET analysis. 3.4 XPS analysis XPS analysis was used to investigate the surface element composition and their chemical states of the catalysts. The results are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 5 . The Ce 3d XPS spectra of Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 are presented in Fig. 5(A). According to previous studies [39,40], the Ce 3d XPS spectra could be separated into 8 peaks. The peaks denoted by “u” and “v” represent the Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 respectively. The peaks labeled u, u2, u3, v, v2 and v3 could be assigned to Ce4+, and the other two peaks labeled u1 and v1 belong to Ce3+ [41–43]. It is obvious that the peak intensities of u, u3, v and v3 are much stronger than that of u1 and v1, revealing that Ce4+ is the mainly valance state of Ce in all catalyst samples and Ce3+ is the secondary state of Ce. Moreover, the ratio of Ce3+/Ce for the two catalyst samples could be calculated from the results of XPS analysis and the results are listed in Table 2. Obviously, the Ce3+/Ce ratio of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 is much higher than that of Ce/TiO2. Previous studies [8,44–46] pointed out that the presence of more Ce3+ could promote the generation of charge imbalance, oxygen vacancies and unsaturated chemical bonds on catalyst surface, subsequently, facilitating the oxidation of NO to NO2. As a result, the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 could be accelerated through the “fast SCR” pathway: 2NH3 +NO+NO2 →2N2 +3H2O [28,47,48]. Thus the higher Ce3+/Ce ratio of CeSmTiO2-0.3 catalyst should be partially responsible for its excellent low-temperature SCR performance. The O1s XPS spectra of Ce/TiO2, Sm/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 are shown in Fig. 5(B). Based on the results reported in previous studies [49–51], the O 1s XPS spectra could be spilt into three peaks: lattice oxygen (B. E.=529.0–530.0eV, denotes as Oα), chemisorbed oxygen (B. E.=531.3–531.9eV, denoted as Oβ), and hydroxyl groups (B. E.=532.7–533.8eV). From Table 2, it can be seen that the concentration of Oβ on CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst (15.63at.%) is much higher than that on Ce/TiO2 catalyst (10.57at.%), agreeing well with the higher Ce3+/Ce ratio of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst. Due to its high mobility, chemisorbed oxygen could easily exchange with gas oxygen and oxygen molecular adsorbed on catalyst surface, thus it is widely regarded as the most active oxygen species in NH3-SCR reaction [6,52]. So the higher Oβ concentration over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst could effectively enhance the oxidation of NO to NO2, as a result, promoting the “fast SCR” reaction over it. In addition, the presence of more surface hydroxyl-like group could provide more Brønsted acid sites for NH3 adsorption. And the formed N H 4 + over Brønsted acid sites could react with NO2 to generate N2 and H2O [53]. 3.5 H2-TPR analysis The redox abilities of the catalyst samples were determined by H2-TPR analysis, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . It is apparent that there is no reduction peak in the profile of pure TiO2. For Sm/TiO2, only a reduction peak could be observed at about 737°C, which could be assigned to the reduction of Sm2O3 [54]. The TPR profile of Ce/TiO2 catalyst contains two reduction peaks at about 406 and 570°C respectively, the former one could be attributed to the reduction of surface oxygen species [50,55]. Combined with the results of XRD and XPS analysis, this peak should be corresponding to the reduction of amorphous CeO2 on the surface of TiO2. And the latter one at about 570°C should be ascribed to the reduction of bulk CeO2 [8]. After the addition of Sm, the reduction peaks move to a lower value, indicating the increased reducibility, especially for CeSm/TiO2-0.3. The reduction peaks in its TPR profile appear at 350 and 535°C respectively. Moreover, the total reduction peak area of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 is also larger than that of the other catalyst samples. Thus CeSm/TiO2-0.3 exhibits the best reducibility among the catalyst samples. 3.6 O2-TPD and NH3-TPD analysis Firstly, O2-TPD analysis was carried out, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . For all the catalyst samples, a broad desorption peak could be found on the profile. But the desorption peaks in the profiles of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 and CeSm/TiO2-0.5 are very weak. It should be noticed that the desorption peak for most catalyst samples begins at about 200°C, while the desorption peak in the profile of Ce/TiO2 appears at about 400°C. Thus the desorption peaks in the profiles of Sm-contained catalyst samples in lower temperature range (<400°C) should be mainly due to the decomposition of SmOx. Based on the mechanism proposed by Topsøe [56], the adsorbed NH3 species over catalyst surface is critical to NH3-SCR reaction. The adsorption capacities of NH3 of different catalyst samples were determined by NH3-TPD analysis. After subtracting the O2 desorption peaks (Fig. 7), the results are exhibited in Fig. 8 . From Fig. 8, it could be seen that one continuous peak lasting from 100 to 500°C appears in the NH3-TPD profile of each catalyst sample. The results imply the presence of acid sites with different thermal stability, including weak Brønsted acid sites, strong Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites [57–59]. Furthermore, the total NH3 adsorption capacity of each sample could be calculated based on the peak area, and the results are summarized in Table 3 . It is clear that CeSm/TiO2-0.3 presents the largest NH3 adsorption capacity among the catalyst samples, which is helpful to promote the NH3-SCR reaction over it. 3.7 NO oxidation According to the study of Long and Yang [60], the enhanced NO oxidation to NO2 over Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst could greatly improve its SCR activity. And our previous study also found that the addition or Zn or Pb on Mn/TiO2 catalyst would inhibit the oxidation of NO to NO2 accompanied by the drop of its SCR performance [61]. Therefore, the NO catalytic oxidation over the three catalyst samples were also tested and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . From Fig. 9, it is evident that the NO conversion to NO2 over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 is much higher than that over Ce/TiO2 and Sm/TiO2. Therefore, the modification of Ce/TiO2 catalyst by Sm could promote the oxidation of NO to NO2, which should be due to the formation of more chemisorbed oxygen on CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst, as reflected by the results of XPS analysis. The promoted formation of NO2 over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst is favorable to the “fast SCR” reaction, which makes a great contribution to the low-temperature SCR activity of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst. 3.8 In situ DRIFT study In this section, the adsorption behavior of reactants and their surface reactions over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst samples were investigated by in situ DRIFT analysis, moreover, the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over the two catalyst samples would be discussed based on the results of in situ DRIFT study. 3.8.1 NH3 adsorption The adsorption and activation of NH3 species over the catalyst plays an important aspect in the NH3-SCR reaction [62]. The in situ DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 are illustrated in Fig. 10 . As shown in Fig. 10(A), the band at 1664 and 1433cm−1 could be assigned to N H 4 + species on Brønsted acid sites [53,63], and the band at 1603 and 1180cm−1 could be attributed to the coordinated NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites [64–67]. Moreover, the weak band at 1330cm−1 could be observed in the DRIFT spectra of Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst at 100°C, which could be ascribed to NH2 species [68]. As an important intermediate in SCR reaction, NH2 could react with NO to form N2 and H2O [66]. Thus the results of DRIFT study agree well with that of NH3-TPD analysis. It is clear that the band intensities of Lewis acid sites are much higher than that of Brønsted acid sites, suggesting that the surface acidity of Ce/TiO2 catalyst is mainly in the form of Lewis acidity, as reported by Wang et al. [8]. Fig. 10(A) indicates that the bands of adsorbed NH3 species decrease with increasing temperature, and the two bands at 1664 and 1433cm−1 nearly disappear at 250°C, on the contrary, the two bands at 1603 and 1180cm−1 are still present at 350°C, suggesting the thermal stability of Lewis acid sites is higher than that of Brønsted acid sites. From Fig. 10(B), it could be observed that the DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst are very similar with that of Ce/TiO2 catalyst, except that the band intensities are stronger than that in the spectra of Ce/TiO2 catalyst. Therefore, the modification of Ce/TiO2 catalyst by Sm could enhance the adsorption of NH3 species, as revealed by the results of NH3-TPD analysis. 3.8.2 NO+O2 adsorption The in situ DRIFT spectra of NO+O2 adsorption over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 are presented in Fig. 11 . Several bands of adsorbed NOx species appear in the DRIFT spectra of Ce/TiO2 catalyst, which could be related to adsorbed NO2 species (1615cm−1) [66], bidentate nitrate (1562cm−1) [69,70], and bridged nitrite (1229cm−1) [71,72] respectively. For the DRIFT spectra of CeSm/TiO2-0.3, a different band could be found at 1908cm−1, corresponding to weakly adsorbed NO species [66]. Comparing with that in the DRIFT spectra of Ce/TiO2 catalyst, a distinct band intensity increase could be seen in the DRIFT spectra of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst. Therefore, the adsorption of NOx species over Ce/TiO2 catalyst is also strengthened by the introduction of Sm. 3.8.3 Reaction between NOx and preadsorbed NH3 species To identify the activity of adsorbed NH3 species in the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3, the in situ DRIFT spectra of the reaction between preadsorbed NH3 species and NO+O2 at 150°C were recorded and the results are presented in Fig. 12 . After the exposure to NH3, several bands of adsorbed NH3 species appeared. From Fig. 12, it is clear that the band of adsorbed NH3 species gradually decreased after the introduction of NO+O2, however, the reaction rate of adsorbed NH3 species seemed to be relatively low, which should be due to that the low reaction temperature was unfavorable to the activation of adsorbed NH3 species. Nearly all the adsorbed NH3 species over Ce/TiO2 catalyst disappeared in about 5min, however, some bands of adsorbed NH3 species over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst were still present after the introduction of NO+O2 for 10min, which should be resulted from the presence of more NH3 species bound to the Lewis acid sites over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst. It would take more time to consume these NH3 species in SCR reaction. As shown in Fig. 10, the band intensity of 1180cm−1 in the spectra of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst is much higher than that in the spectra of Ce/TiO2 catalyst. Besides that, the band at 1180cm−1 moved to higher wavenumber after the introduction of NO+O2, which should be due to the quick growth of the band at 1235cm−1, indicating the replacement of adsorbed NH3 species by NOx species. In addition, several bands of adsorbed NOx species appeared with the consumption of adsorbed NH3 species. Thus all the adsorbed NH3 species are involved the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3, revealing the presence of E-R mechanism [73]. 3.8.4 Reaction between NH3 and preadsorbed NOx species As another aspect, the in situ DRIFT spectra of the reaction between preadsorbed NOx and NH3 species were also recorded, and the results are depicted in Fig. 13 . Several bands belonging to adsorbed NOx species could be observed on the surface of Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 after the pretreatment with NOx. However, not all the adsorbed NOx species could take part in the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3. The two bands at 1615 and 1229cm−1 quickly vanished after the introduction of NH3 for 2min, demonstrating the existence of the L–H mechanism [31]. On the contrary, the band at 1562cm−1 kept stable in the whole reaction process. Thus not all the adsorbed NOx species are active in the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3. In our previous study [72], we also found that bidentate nitrate was inactive in the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 catalyst. And the study of Liu et al. [66] also indicated that some bridge nitrate and bidentate nitrate were inert in the NH3-SCR reaction over Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst. From the results shown in Figs. 12 and 13, it may be concluded that the adsorbed NOx species are much more active that the adsorbed NH3 species, suggesting that L-H mechanism should be more important in the SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 at low temperature range, which is in good accordance with the results of Chen et al. [73]. They found that the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 catalyst was mainly controlled by L-H mechanism at low temperature (<200°C). 3.9 Effect of reaction temperature As shown in Fig. 1(A), the SCR activity of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst is much higher than that of Ce/TiO2 catalyst in the low temperature range (<200°C), but the activity difference nearly vanishes at 250°C. Thus the effect of reaction temperature on the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 should be investigated. According to the method proposed by Yang et al. [74], the contributions of E-R and L-H mechanisms to NH3-SCR reaction could be obtained. In this experiment, the effect of NO inlet concentration on the SCR activities of Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 was tested, as shown in Fig. 14 . During the test process, the inlet concentrations of NO and NH3 were all kept the same to ensure the full SCR reaction. If the NH3-SCR reaction over a catalyst is mainly controlled by the E-R mechanism, its SCR activity should not decrease with the NO inlet concentration increasing from 600ppm to 1200ppm. On the other hand, if the NH3-SCR reaction over a catalyst mainly obeys by L-H mechanism, the value of NOx conversion should halve under the same NO inlet concentration change. From the results presented in Fig. 14, it is distinct that E-R and L-H mechanisms are all suitable for the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3. Based on the results of this study and previous literatures [31,75], the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 and CeSm/TiO2-0.3 mainly follows the two pathways as below: (A) E-R mechanism: NH3 is adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, followed by oxidation to NH2, then the formed NH2 reacts with gaseous NO to form N2 and H2O. (3) NH 3 ( g ) → Ce 4 + NH 3 ( a ) ( L e w i s a c i d s i t e s ) (4) O 2 ( g ) → 2 O ( a ) (5) NH 3 ( a ) + O ( a ) → NH 2 ( a ) + OH ( a ) (6) NO ( g ) + NH 2 ( a ) → NH 2 NO ( a ) (7) NH 2 NO ( a ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O (B) L-H mechanism: adsorbed NO2 and coordinated NH3 are the main active species in the NH3-SCR reaction under this way. (8) NO + O 2 ( g ) → NO 2 ( a ) (9) NH 3 ( g ) → Ce 4 + NH 3 ( a ) ( L e w i s a c i d s i t e s ) (10) NO 2 ( a ) + 2 NH 3 ( a ) + NO ( g ) → 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O Moreover, we could obtain the values of reaction rate through E-R and L-H mechanisms by performing a SBET normalization. The ratio of CL-H/(CL-H+CE-R) could be seen as the contribution of L-H mechanism to NH3-SCR reaction, which is also presented in Fig. 15 . Fig. 15 depicts that the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 catalyst is mainly controlled by L-H mechanism at 100°C, and the contribution of E-R mechanism increases with reaction temperature. When the reaction temperature is over 150°C, the NH3-SCR reaction over Ce/TiO2 catalyst mainly follow the E-R mechanism. Due to the inhibited NH3 activation and NO oxidation at low temperature, Ce/TiO2 catalyst only presents low SCR activity below 200°C (Fig. 1(A)). For CeSm/TiO2-0.3, it is noticeable that the L-H mechanism is more important in the NH3-SCR reaction over it at low temperature range (<200°C). For example, the contribution of L-H mechanism is 59.5% at 150°C for CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst, while the corresponding value for Ce/TiO2 catalyst is only 38.6%. So the enhanced NO oxidation and NH3 adsorption over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 should be the primary reason for its distinguished low-temperature SCR performance. 4 Conclusions In this study, Sm was introduced into Ce/TiO2 catalyst to enhance its low temperature SCR performance. The experimental results demonstrated that CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst presented an excellent low-temperature SCR activity and good SO2/H2O tolerance. From the characterization results, it could be found that the modification of Ce/TiO2 catalyst by Sm could generate more Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen species, therefore, promoting its reducibility and the oxidation of NO to NO2, accompanied by the enhanced NH3 adsorption. As a result, the NH3-SCR reaction over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 was greatly facilitated in the low temperature range (<200°C). coredata.dc:description: CeSmOx mixed oxide catalysts supported on TiO2 prepared by coprecipitation method were used for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3. The results showed that the addition of Sm could effectively enhance the low-temperature SCR activity and SO2/H2O resistance of Ce/TiO2 catalyst, and the appropriate mole ratio of Sm to Ce was 0.3. Characterization results indicated that the introduction of Sm could promote the formation of Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen species on catalyst surface, which was favorable to the generation of NO2. Moreover, the doping of Sm could also promote the adsorption of NH3 and NOx species on Ce/TiO2 catalyst. The results of in situ DRIFT study revealed that the NH3-SCR reaction over CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst was mainly controlled by the Langmuir−Hinshelwood mechanism in the low temperature range (<200°C). Thereafter, the promoted NO oxidation and the enhanced NH3 adsorption should play a major role for the excellent low-temperature SCR performance of CeSm/TiO2-0.3 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement of the low-temperature activity of Ce/TiO2 catalyst by Sm modification for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3
